intro: Isodon silvaticus, commonly known as the mountain verbena, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are small, clustered in whorls, and range in color from blue to purple, attracting various pollinators. Isodon silvaticus is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade.
